thread.title: 10,000 Arsenal fans set to - very conveniently - boycott Hull game
thread.title_full: 10,000 Arsenal fans set to - very conveniently - boycott Hull game

title: 10,000 Arsenal fans set to - very conveniently - boycott Hull game
text:
10,000 Arsenal fans set to – very conveniently – boycott Hull game By Paul Morrissey on Saturday, February 11, 2017 Arsenal’s ‘Wenger Out’ Brigade 
With their team seemingly locked in a perpetual race for 4th place, a schism has developed between Arsenal fans, in the form of a ‘Wenger Out’ Brigade and a loyal ‘Arsene Knows Best’ opposition group. 
The former are becoming increasingly vocal, particularly on Arsenal Fan TV, where the likes of Troopz and DT have been whipping their acolytes up into a frenzy following Arsenal’s regular home defeats. 
With Wenger’s current contract up at the end of the season, the ‘Wenger Out’ brigade are hoping that the Frenchman does the honorable thing and walks away from the job in the summer, rather than accepting the new 2-year contract which has been tabled. 
This group of fans is convinced that Wenger will never be able to win another title as Arsenal manager, and that the best thing now would be to step aside and let someone else take charge. 10,000 fans to (conveniently) boycott Hull game 
Last weekend’s defeat at Chelsea felt like a tipping point; it essentially put an end to Arsenal’s season, because no one in their right mind thinks the Gunners can win the Champions League. 
So it looks like the remainder of the league season could see the situation become even more toxic, with the Wenger Out brigade set to protest and campaign for Wenger’s departure. 
As of today. 
Up to 10,000 fans are expected to boycott today’s game against Hull – rather conveniently, it must be said. 
The Supporters Trust spokesman had no qualms in admitting that the context of today’s game – a lunchtime kickoff (which is live on TV) on a cold winter’s day – plays a big part. 
Speaking to the Evening Standard , Arsenal Supporters Trust spokesman Tim Payton explained the situation: 
“With the composition of the fanbase these days, the most likely protest will be in the form of empty seats. 
“Fans I talk to are extremely frustrated but there is no great desire for organised protest aimed directly at Arsene Wenger given all he has achieved at the club and the result is that many fans simply can’t face going every week.” 
Add in the fact it is a lunchtime kick-off on a cold weekend at the start of half-term against modest opposition and the crowd could be 10,000 below capacity.
